pageData.text: In this investigation, students will experimentally rank the chemical activities of copper, iron, and magnesium. Students will determine if a reaction will reduce a <button class='glossary-text'>metal</button> ion to a pure metal based on reactions between metals and salt solutions.

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.desc: Preparation: 10 minutes, Activity 1: Creating a Metal Activity Series: 15 minutes, Cleanup: 5 minutes
pageData.altText: Preparation: 10 minutes, Activity 1: Creating a Metal Activity Series: 15 minutes, Cleanup: 5 minutes

pageData.title: Overview Video: Developing an Activity Series
Outcomes
text: Determine whether salt solutions will reduce <button class='glossary-text'>metal</button> ions to pure metal.
Rank metals from most reactive to least reactive.
Write half-reactions and net ionic equations for each reaction.
Identify the oxidizing and reducing agents and which substances are oxidized and reduced.

pageData.text: Batteries can manipulate the use of chemical energy’s ability to store electrical energy. They do this by taking advantage of the reactivities of <button class='glossary-text'>metals</button> like zinc, manganese, lithium, and lead. Such reactivity can power a device via the movement of electrons; they occur until the anode is out of electrons, generally after the battery component called the electrolyte has been exhausted. These redox reactions cause the pressure within the battery to increase as hydrogen gas is produced as a byproduct of the breakdown water from the electrolyte. Usually, the seals at the top and bottom of the battery are secure enough to contain these pressures. However, for reasons such as age or improper use, these seals can break and the battery leaks the excess hydrogen gas, forcing out the liquid electrolyte (i.e., potassium hydroxide or KOH). The KOH reacts with carbon dioxide (CO<sub className=bodySubscript>2</sub>) in the air and creates the salt potassium carbonate (K<sub className=bodySubscript>2</sub>CO<sub className=bodySubscript>3</sub>), which appears as a white crystalline residue.

pageData.desc: A small cylindrical battery covered in a crystalline residue.
pageData.altText: A small cylindrical battery covered in a crystalline residue.

pageData.text: A is characterized by the ability to lose outer-level electrons, which results in the formation of a . This process is called . The reactivity of a metal is based on the ability to become oxidized. Metals that have a greater tendency to lose electrons and become oxidized are more reactive. Metals are ranked from most reactive to least reactive in a table called the (Figure 1).Notice that gold and silver are near the bottom of the activity series, indicating that these metals are less reactive due to a stronger attraction for the outer electrons. This is why these metals are sometimes found in nature as pure metals. Ancient civilizations used copper, silver, and gold coins as currencies, because these metals do not oxidize or lose their luster as easily as that of other metals. Oxidation is common. Iron and steel structures lose electrons and corrode. This results in the formation of Fe3+ ions, which react with oxygen to produce iron (III) oxide (Fe2O3), or rust.

tableData.text:
A metal that is listed high on the activity series table will:
•   be more reactive.
•   be more easily oxidized
(i.e., more easily lose its electrons).
•   more vigorously react with chemicals.
•   more easily corrode.
tableData.hoverText: A metal that is listed high on the activity series table will: •   be more reactive. •   be more easily oxidized (i.e., more easily lose its electrons). •   more vigorously react with chemicals. •   more easily corrode.

tableData.text:
A metal that is listed low on the activity series table will:
•   react less vigorously and less quickly with chemicals.
•   corrode less easily
tableData.hoverText: A metal that is listed low on the activity series table will:  •   react less vigorously and less quickly with chemicals. •   corrode less easily

pageData.text: An <button class='glossary-text'>oxidation</button> reaction, which is a loss of electrons with an increase in charge, requires an accompanying reduction reaction, or a gain of electrons with a reduction in charge. The <button class='glossary-text'>Metal Activity Series</button> table (<button class='resource-text'>Figure 1</button>) ranks elements according to chemical activity. This table can be used to predict whether a <button class='glossary-text'>metal</button> will spontaneously react with the ions of another metal. For example, this table can be used to predict if a strip of copper metal will react with an aqueous solution of silver nitrate (AgNO<sub className=bodySubscript>3</sub>) (Figure 2).

pageData.desc: Figure 2: Image showing copper strip reacting with a silver nitrate solution. Copper ionizes and silver deposits as a solid on the copper.
pageData.altText: Figure 2: Image showing copper strip reacting with a silver nitrate solution. Copper ionizes and silver deposits as a solid on the copper.

pageData.question: A metal that is listed high on the activity series table will:

options.text: not oxidize or lose their luster
have a stronger attraction to other metals

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: A metal that is listed high on the activity series table will be more reactive, be more easily oxidized (i.e., more easily lose its electrons), more vigorously react with chemicals, and more easily corrode.

pageData.question: Ancient civilizations used ______ coins as currency because these metals do not oxidize or lose their luster as easily as other metals.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Copper, silver, and gold do not oxidize or lose their luster as easily as that of other metals.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: A metal that is listed low on the activity series table will react less vigorously and less quickly with chemicals and corrode less easily. Ancient civilizations used different metal coins as currencies, because these metals do not oxidize or lose their luster as easily as that of other metals. Oxidation is common. For example, iron and steel structures lose electrons and corrode. This results in the formation of Fe<sup>3+</sup> ions, which react with oxygen to produce iron (III) oxide (Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>), or rust.

pageData.text: The net ionic equation below shows the reaction. This is classified as a single-displacement reaction, because copper displaces the silver ion from the aqueous silver-nitrate solution. Cu(s) + 2 Ag+(aq) → Cu+2(aq) + 2 Ag(s)Copper is listed higher than silver in the (). Thus, copper should oxidize in the silver-nitrate solution to form Cu2+ ions. The copper strip will dissolve, causing the solution to become blue due to the presence of Cu2+ ions. of copper releases two electrons as shown in the following equation; thus, copper is the reducing agent for the Ag+ ions.Cu(s) → Cu2+(aq) + 2 e-Two silver ions will be reduced to two silver atoms by gaining the two electrons lost by each copper atom. Solid silver crystals will form on the surface of the copper strip as they are removed from the aqueous silver-nitrate solution. The Ag+ ions act as oxidizing agents for the copper atoms.2 Ag+(aq) + 2 e- → 2 Ag(s)

The reduction and oxidation reactions are each referred to as a half reaction, because each represents half of the entire reaction. The overall net ionic reaction can be written as follows: Cu(s) → Cu2+(aq) + 2 e- oxidation (half reaction) 2 Ag+(aq) + 2 e- → 2 Ag(s) reduction (half reaction) Cu(s) + 2 Ag+(aq) → Cu2+(aq) + 2 Ag(s) net ionic equation (redox reaction) This reaction is often called a redox reaction (red from “reduction” and ox from “oxidation”). Notice that the loss and gain of electrons are equal, and that the mass and charge are the same on both sides of the net equation. To summarize, if A is higher than Metal B in the activity series, then a spontaneous chemical reaction will occur if Metal A is placed in a solution of Metal B ions. Metal A is oxidized, and Metal B is reduced. Metal A is the reducing agent, and Metal B is the oxidizing agent.

pageData.question: The reactions you will be performing in this investigation are often referred to as _______.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The reactions you will be performing in this investigation are often referred to as redox reactions (red from “reduction” and ox from “oxidation”).

pageData.question: If Metal A is put into an aqueous solution of Metal B, and reacts according to the chemical equation shown, which of the following is the reducing agent?A(s) + 2 B+(aq) --> A2+ + 2 B(s)

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Metal A is oxidized, and Metal B is reduced. Metal A is the reducing agent, and Metal B is the oxidizing agent.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The Metal Activity Series table ranks elements according to chemical activity. This table can be used to predict whether a metal will spontaneously react with the ions of another metal. For example, this table can be used to predict if a strip of copper metal will react with an aqueous solution of silver nitrate (AgNO<sub className=bodySubscript>3</sub>). Copper is listed higher than silver in the Metal Activity Series. Thus, copper should oxidize in the silver-nitrate solution to form Cu<sup className=bodySupscript>2+</sup> ions. The copper strip will dissolve, causing the solution to become blue due to the presence of Cu<sup className=bodySupscript>2+</sup> ions. Oxidation of copper releases two electrons, thus, copper is the reducing agent for the Ag<sup className=bodySupscript>+</sup> ions. The reduction and oxidation reactions are each referred to as a half reaction, because each represents half of the entire reaction.

Wear your safety goggles, chemical apron, and gloves at all times while conducting this investigation.

pageData.desc: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol

pageData.text: Read all the instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE).
Magnesium ribbon is a combustible metal. Keep chemical away from any heat or flame sources.

Iron (II) sulfate and copper (II) sulfate are skin/eye irritants and ingestion hazards. Keep chemicals away from food storage locations to avoid accidental ingestion. In the event of contact with skin or eyes, the affected area should be immediately rinsed with water for 15 minutes.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum during this laboratory activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after this activity. Clean up the lab area with soap and water after completing this investigation.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

What is the net ionic equation that can be written from the two half reactions below?3 Pt --> 3 Pt2+ + 6 e-2 Au3+ + 6 e- --> 2 Au

options.text: Metal A is higher than Metal B on the activity series.
Metal B is higher than Metal A on the activity series.
Metal A gains more electrons than Metal B.
Metal B gains more electrons than Metal A.
Metal A and Metal B are ranked equally on the activity series.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: Congratulations!!! You passed the Pre-lab Assessment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: You have not passed the pre-lab assessment. You must score 100% to unlock the rest of the investigation. Please review the pre-lab sections again before re-attempting this assessment. You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Read the activity.
Obtain all of the materials.
Clean and sanitize the work space.
Obtain a piece of sandpaper or an emery board. Cut it into three equal pieces.
Use a pair of scissors to cut a 6-cm piece of magnesium ribbon (provided in the chemical kit).

Use sandpaper to polish three pieces of copper wire, three iron straight pins, and the strip of magnesium. Polish away the top layer of tarnish (or coating) on each side of each piece of <button class='glossary-text'>metal</button> until there is a clear, shiny surface. To polish wire or a straight pin, hold the wire or pin, and move the bottom half back and forth across the sandpaper. Cut the polished magnesium ribbon into three equal pieces of approximately 2 cm in length.
Be very careful during this step. Hold the pin firmly and do not touch the sharp point of the pin when you are polishing.

Orient the reaction tray to have four rows of five wells (compartments). This will be the testing matrix for the three metals. One row of wells will be used for each metal (magnesium, iron, and copper, respectively).

Refer to the reaction tray image (Figure 3). Use a permanent marker to write the names of the ions Mg<sup className=bodySupscript>2+</sup>, Fe<sup className=bodySupscript>2+</sup>, Cu<sup className=bodySupscript>2+</sup> and the metals Mg, Fe, and Cu as shown in Figure 3.

pageData.altText: Figure 3: Reaction tray with labels. Magnesium, iron, and copper ions are labeled in the second, third, and fourth wells of row one, respectively. Magnesium, iron, and copper metal are labeled in the second, third, and fourth wells of column one, respectively.

pageData.text: In this activity, you will create a <button class='glossary-text'>metal activity series</button> by reacting samples of magnesium, iron and copper <button class='glossary-text'>metal</button> with aqueous solutions of magnesium, iron, and copper ions. You will observe each metal-solution combination for evidence of chemical activity and rank the metals by the number of chemical reactions they generated.

pages.title: Creating a Metal Activity Series (10 steps)

pageData.text: Place 10 drops of MgSO<sub className=bodySubscript>4</sub> in each of the three wells below the label “Mg<sup className=bodySupscript>2+</sup>.”
Place 10 drops of FeSO<sub className=bodySubscript>4</sub> in each of the three wells below the label “Fe<sup className=bodySupscript>2+</sup>.”
Place 10 drops of CuSO<sub className=bodySubscript>4</sub> in each of the three wells below the label “Cu<sup className=bodySupscript>2+</sup>.”
Place one piece of magnesium ribbon in each of the three wells to the right of the label “Mg” that contains an ionic solution.
Place one piece of iron (a steel straight pin) in each of the three wells to the right of the label “Fe” that contains an ionic solution.
Place one piece of copper wire in each of the three wells to the right of the label “Cu” that contains an ionic solution.
Allow each <button class='glossary-text'>metal</button> to remain in the ionic solutions for five minutes.
Observe the wells closely during this time. You may need to use the forceps to pick up the metal pieces to examine them more closely.
Photograph the reaction tray showing all wells, and record all evidence of chemical activity, such as color changes or the production of gas bubbles or heat, in Data Table 1.
After five minutes, determine how many chemical reactions occurred for each metal. Record the number of reactions in Data Table 1.

text: Rinse the tray and solid metals. The ionic solutions can be disposed of by rinsing them down the drain.

Discard the used <button class='glossary-text'>metal</button> pieces in the trash. If your kit includes the Electrochemistry investigation, keep all materials and chemicals from this investigation for future use in the Electrochemistry investigation. When your course is complete, the tray and metals can be thrown in the trash.
Clean and sanitize the work space.

pageData.text: You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.
pageData.confirmationMessage: Are you sure you want to submit your work? You will not be able to edit the lab notebook after submitting your work.

text: Use the number of reactions in Data Table 1 to list the metals copper, iron, and magnesium in order from most reactive to least reactive.

Summarize the redox reactions that you observed in this investigation. List the reactions in descending order of activity, referring to Data Table 1.For each reaction in the data table, perform the following steps:
  • Write the overall single-displacement reaction.
  • Write the half-cell reaction for oxidation.
  • Write the half-cell reaction for reduction.
  • Add the two half-cell reactions, and write the net ionic equation.
  • Identify the reducing agent.
  • Identify the oxidizing agent.
Copy and paste the following format to report your answers for each reaction in the space below.
  • Overall reaction
  • Oxidation
  • Reduction
  • Net ionic reaction
  • Reducing agent
  • Oxidizing agent

data.title: Cation
data.content: An ion with net positive charge

data.title: Metal
data.content: An element that is characterized by the ability to lose outer-level electrons, generally is shiny, malleable, and a good conductor of heat and electricity

data.title: Metal activity series
data.content: Metals are ranked from most reactive to least reactive

data.title: Oxidation
data.content: The loss of one or more electrons during a reaction by a molecule, atom or ion
